set forth in the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 51-1957. Passed 11-1-57.)
   131.02 POLICE RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS.
   Section intentionally left blank. 
   131.03 DIVISION OF POLICE ORGANIZATION.
   (a)   In accordance with Section
7.03 of the Charter, the following ranks, positions, offices and organization
are hereby established, together with authorized personnel, within the Division
of Police:
 
Title                                 No. of Personnel Authorized  
Chief of Police                       1
Assistant Chief                       As determined
Lieutenants                           by
Sergeants                             Mayor

Patrol Officers (full or part-time)
Full-time Radio Dispatcher (I and II)
   (b)   The Mayor may authorize the future employment of part-time personnel,
consistent with the monetary appropriations available from Council. All
regular, full-time personnel below the rank of Assistant Chief shall be
appointed and promoted in accordance with the Twinsburg Civil Service
Commission rules and regulations. All duties performed by personnel within such
Division shall be prescribed by the Mayor and Chief of Police and shall be set
forth in the Twinsburg Police Manual which is hereby fully adopted by this
reference; the officially adopted copy of which as amended by the Police Chief
shall be kept in both the Offices of the Chief of Police and the Clerk of
Council. All part-time personnel shall be within the unclassified civil service
status and non-bargaining unit positions of the City and shall be appointed at
the discretion of the Mayor consistent with the monetary appropriations
available from Council provided, however, that the Mayor may require certain
testing and minimum qualifying conditions to receive an original appointment as
a part-time employee, but such employees may be dismissed by the Mayor with or
without cause.
       
   (c)   Should the present Twinsburg Police Manual be, in any manner,
inconsistent with the foregoing, the Chief of Police is hereby directed to
amend the Manual in accord herewith. (Ord. 44-2011. Passed 4-26-11.)
   131.04 DIVISION OF FIRE ORGANIZATION.
      (a)    In accordance with Section
7.03 of the Charter, the following ranks, positions, offices and organization
are hereby established, together with authorized personnel, within the Division
of Fire:
 
 
Title                                         No. of Personnel Authorized
Fire Chief                                    1
Assistant Fire Chief
Captain(s)
Lieutenant(s)                                 As determined by Mayor
Firefighter/Paramedic(s): (full or part-time)
Cadet/Recruit(s)
All regular, full-time personnel below the rank of Assistant Fire Chief shall
be appointed in accordance with the Twinsburg Civil Service Commission rules
and regulations. All regular, full-time personnel below the rank of Assistant
Fire Chief shall be promoted in accordance with the Twinsburg Civil Service
Commission rules and regulations or an applicable collective bargaining
agreement. All duties performed by personnel within such Division shall be
prescribed by the Mayor and Fire Chief and shall be set forth in the Standard
Operating Procedures which are hereby fully adopted by this reference; the
officially adopted copy of which as amended by the Fire Chief shall be kept in
both the Offices of the Fire Chief and the Clerk of Council. The Mayor may
authorize the future employment of part-time and cadet/recruit personnel,
consistent with the monetary appropriations available from Council. All part-
time and cadet/recruit personnel shall be within the unclassified civil service
status and non-bargaining unit positions of the City and shall be appointed at
the discretion of the Mayor consistent with the monetary appropriations
available from Council provided, however, that the Mayor may require certain
testing and minimum qualifying conditions to receive an original appointment as
a part-time or cadet/recruit employee, but such employees may be dismissed by
the Mayor with or without cause.
   (b)   Except as otherwise provided herein, such Firefighter/ Paramedics
shall be at least eighteen (18) years of age at the time of original
appointment. Determination of whether candidates are suitable for appointment
shall be made by the Fire Chief. After receiving a conditional job offer,
candidates will be subject to a medical and physical examination made in a
manner prescribed by the Fire Chief and approved by the Safety Director. A
cadet/recruit may commence service at eighteen (18) years of age, and must
possess a high school diploma or G.E.D. and meet other requirements as
determined by the Fire Chief.
      (c)    All appointments made under subsection (a) hereof shall be for a
probationary period as set forth in the current contract between the City of
Twinsburg and the Fire Department Labor Organization, Twinsburg's Civil Service
Rules and Regulations, or Chapter
147 herein, whichever is applicable.
      (d)    The Fire Chief shall:
      (1)    Take charge and custody of all fire apparatus and equipment and
supervise the maintenance thereof so that the same may be in good order and
condition and ready for use at all times;
      (2)    Have full control of the Fire Division and its members during all
fires and emergencies and may at any time during a fire call or emergency, call
upon any citizen or citizens to perform labor, which in his judgment is
necessary to aid in the extinguishing of fires; and
      (3)    Have such other and further duties and responsibilities as may be
provided by law or assigned to him by the Director of Public Safety.
      (e)    Each regular firefighter and officer shall receive as compensation
that amount approved by Council.
      (f)    The Fire Division created hereby is a governmental unit and shall
have no official connection whatsoever with any fire companies privately
organized for any purpose, other than the fact that its members may also be
members of such companies or contracts with companies as might be authorized by
Council, if any.
      (g)    The Fire Division hereby created shall be bound by any contract
that may be made by Council with any other municipality or township or any
other party with which the City is authorized to legally contract according to
the terms thereof.
     (h)    The Fire Chief and the Safety Director shall be responsible for the
personnel morale and general efficiency of the Division. The Fire Chief and
Safety Director shall formulate and submit to Council any additional rules and
regulations to govern the Division and upon approval thereof by Council a copy
thereof shall be furnished to each member of the Division and to the Clerk of
Council, which copy the Clerk shall file in the permanent records of the City.
       (i)    The Fire Chief shall assemble the officers and firefighters for
the purpose of instruction and drill in the operation and understanding of all
phases of the work which have a bearing upon good firefighters to maintain
proficiency as recommended by State and National Standards for Fire, EMS,
HAZMAT and Special Operations performed by the Fire Department.
     (j)    The Division may organize for social interests providing there is
no interference with its general efficiency and provided that none of the
provisions of their social organization shall be in conflict with any of the
terms of this section and expenditure of moneys shall be in accordance with
standards established by the Bureau of Public Inspection, Ohio State Auditor's
Office. No Division funds, however received, may be used for social events
without prior approval of the finance director and must be deposited with the
Finance Director except outright gifts and contributions not involving the use
of Fire Division personnel or equipment as consideration therefore.
   (k)   The Fire Chief is hereby required to cause inspections to be made for
all buildings and premises within the Fire District of Twinsburg, except those
buildings used exclusively for residential purposes, as determined by the
Occupancy Hazard classifications in the N.F.P.A.'s Fire Protection Handbook,
most current edition each year. All high hazard occupancies will be inspected
at least twice each year and all low and medium hazard occupancies will be
inspected at least once each year. The Fire Prevention Bureau will classify all
occupancies by hazard classification to meet this requirement. The Fire Chief
and/or his inspectors are further required to serve written notice upon the
owner of any building or premises to abate, within a specified time, any and
all fire hazards or hazards that may be found therein or thereon.
   (l)   Any person, firm or corporation so served with an order to abate any
fire hazard or hazards, shall comply with such order forthwith, and thereupon
notify the Fire Chief or the Fire Marshal.
      (m)    All personal cars of Fire Division members may be classified as
public safety vehicles as set forth in Section
301.27 of the Traffic Code provided provisions of Section
337.19 of the Traffic Code are observed. A record of such vehicles shall be
prepared by the Fire Chief and filed with the Twinsburg Police Department.
       (n)    It is hereby made the special duty of the Police Chief, policemen
and such other peace officers as are on duty at the time, to respond to all
fire alarms and assist the Fire Division in the protection of the life of the
Citizens of the City and the property therein, and the property of the Fire
Division and in controlling and regulating traffic and maintaining order.
(Ord. 42-2020. Passed 5-26-20; Ord. 133-2023. Passed 12-12-23.)
   131.05 POLICE AGE REQUIREMENTS.
   No person shall be eligible to receive an original appointment as a police
patrolman within the Division of Police, Department of Public Safety of the
City unless he or she has attained the age of twenty-one years and has passed a
physical examination given by a licensed physician showing that he or she meets
the physical requirements necessary to perform the duties of such office. The
appointment authority shall, prior to making any such appointment, file with
the Police and Firemens’ Disability and Pension Fund, a copy of the report of
findings of such licensed physician. The professional fees for such physical
examination shall be paid by the City.
(Ord. 49-2006. Passed 5-23-06.) 
   131.06 AUTHORIZATION OF INVESTIGATION EXPENDITURES.
   The Chief of Police is hereby authorized and directed to make and approve
such necessary investigative and evidence gathering expenses as he, in his sole
discretion deems appropriate, in the prosecution of persons engaged in criminal
activities within the corporate limits, which miscellaneous moneys shall be
paid from the Miscellaneous Expense Account of the Twinsburg Police Department,
being part of the General Fund. The Chief of Police shall approve by vouchers
all such expenses for the purposes herein mentioned and shall refer to the case
involved, the date and time that the expenditure was incurred, the purpose for
each expenditure, to whom such moneys were paid and such other pertinent data
as can readily be verified by audit in the future.
(Ord. 42-1974. Passed 3-12-74.)
   131.07 JURISDICTION OF SAFETY FORCES OUTSIDE CITY.
   (a) The safety forces of the City of Twinsburg including police, fire and
building officials are authorized to exercise jurisdiction and to enforce all
laws and regulations of the City of Twinsburg on all property owned by the City
beyond its limits.
   (b) Law enforcement officers are empowered to make arrests and issue
citations and to invoke the jurisdiction of the Stow Municipal Court on such
property.
(Ord. 44-2011. Passed 4-26-11.)
CHAPTER 133
Municipal Engineer
133.01    Creation.
133.02   Qualifications.
133.03   Term of employment. (Deleted)
133.04   Duties.
133.05   Office.
133.06   Appointment.
133.07   Wage coordinator.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Authority to establish position - see CHTR. §
7.01
         Responsible for enforcement of Building Code - see BLDG.
1321.01
   133.01 CREATION.
   The position of Municipal Engineer is hereby created and established within
the unclassified service of the Municipality.
(Ord. 11-1984. Passed 1-24-84.)
   133.02 QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Engineer shall be a civil engineer and registered as a professional
engineer as required by Ohio R.C. Chapter 4733.
(Ord. 30-1959. Passed 5-1-59.)
   133.03 TERM OF EMPLOYMENT. (DELETED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former Section
133.03 was repealed and deleted pursuant to Ordinance 11-1984, passed January
24, 1984.)
   133.04 DUTIES.
   The Engineer shall:
   (a)    Prepare all necessary plans, profiles, specifications and estimates
of every kind for all public improvements;
   (b)    Serve as the authorized representative of the Municipality and
supervise the execution of public work undertaken by the Municipality pursuant
to plans and specifications approved by Council;
   (c)    Supervise and direct all inspectors and such inspectors shall report
to and receive their instructions from him, relative to the improvements
covered by contract;
   (d)    At the request of the Mayor, furnish plans, specifications and
estimates of cost of all improvements for the guidance of Council and Municipal
officials and for the information and guidance of other persons dealing with
the City;
   (e)    Upon request, make and deliver to the Mayor and Council, reports of
the progress of improvements under his charge;
   (f)   Make his services available to any department of the Municipality upon
approval of the Mayor; (Ord. 86-1978. Passed 7-25-78.)
   (g)    Attend all meetings of Council as required by the Mayor.
      (Ord. 11-1984. Passed 1-24-84.)
   133.05 OFFICE.
   The Mayor may provide an office in the Municipal Building for occupancy by
the Engineer.
   133.06 APPOINTMENT.
   The appointment of the Engineer shall be made by the Mayor.
   133.07 WAGE COORDINATOR.
   (a)    The City Engineer is hereby designated to serve as the Prevailing
Wage Coordinator under Ohio R.C. 4115.071, as pertains to all municipal
contracts involving payment of wages to employees. His duties shall include:
      (1)    The establishment of files of payroll reports to be submitted by
contractors and subcontractors which shall be available for public inspection.
      (2)    To ascertain from each such person at the beginning of the
municipal contract, the dates when payment of wages to employees are to be
made.
      (3)    To receive a complete payroll from contractors or subcontractors
setting forth in detail payments made to employees, hourly rates, job
classifications, fringe benefits, deductions, etc.
      (4)    To establish and follow procedures to monitor compliance hereof by
each contractor and to assure the timely filing of all records by them.
      (5)    Reporting any delinquency to the Mayor.
   (b)    Each contractor and subcontractor doing business with the City shall
be subject to the terms of this section and to Ohio R.C. Chapter 4115 and he
shall comply therewith.
   (c)    Whoever violates this section shall be fined five hundred dollars
($500.00) for a first offense and one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each
subsequent offense.
(Res. 47-1975. Passed 4-22-75.)
CHAPTER 135
Department of Parks and Recreation
135.01   Establishment; purpose.
135.02   Authority.
135.03   Rules and regulations.
135.04   Funds.
135.05   Budget.
135.06   Annual report.
135.07   Staff.
CROSS REFERENCES
         City to have a Parks and Recreation Commission - see CHTR. §
7.01
         Powers of Department - see Ohio R.C. 755.14 et seq.
         Employees' provisions - see ADM. Ch.
147
         Park and recreation fees - see S.U. & P.S.
925.02
         Open meetings - see ADM. Ch.
107
   135.01 ESTABLISHMENT; PURPOSE.
   A Department of Parks and Recreation is hereby established under authority
of Section
7.01 of the Municipal Charter, and the Mayor shall be the head of such
Department. Such Department shall be a separate and distinct administrative
entity and of equal administrative rank with the Department of Public Safety
and the Department of Public Service. Such Department is established for the
purpose of providing for the proper supervision, maintenance and operation of
public parks, playgrounds and other recreational facilities belonging to the
Municipality and to provide for the acquisition of land, structures and other
facilities for the park and recreation program of the Municipality. The
Department of Parks and Recreation shall have the authority to equip, operate,
supervise and maintain public parks, playgrounds, playfields, gymnasiums,
swimming pools, indoor and outdoor recreational centers and facilities for
adults or children as the same are now or shall be owned or controlled by the
Municipality or by the Board of Education of the Municipal School District. The
Department shall have the power to conduct any form of recreation or cultural
activity that will employ the leisure time of the people in a wholesome and
constructive manner. It may conduct such activities on properties under its
control, on public property with the consent of the authorities responsible
therefor, and on private properties with the consent of the owners thereof.
(Ord. 33-1965. Passed 4-27-65.)
   135.02 AUTHORITY.
   The Department of Parks and Recreation shall have all powers provided for
and granted to the Recreation Board under the general laws of the State and
shall specifically have the power to conduct any form of recreational or
cultural activity and shall have control and supervision of all parks belonging
to the Municipality, and may plan, promote, manage and acquire, construct,
develop and operate either within or without the corporate limits, parks,
squares, parkways, community buildings, play and recreation grounds and
buildings of whatever nature or other similar recreation facilities and improve
and ornament the same. The Department may enter into any contract in writing
subject, however, to the prior approval of Council, acting independently or in
conjunction with the State or the United States government, or any county,
municipality, park, district, school district or any other such public
organization for the purpose of conducting a recreation program or exercising
any other power granted in this chapter. The Department may also solicit or
receive on behalf of Council any gifts or bequests of money or other personal
property or any donations which are to be applied, principal or income, for
either the temporary or permanent use of playgrounds, parks or other
recreational purposes. The powers of such Department shall include the
authority to grant concessions and privileges hereunder subject to such
conditions and for such compensation as it shall prescribe. Sale or consumption
of alcoholic beverages in public parks is prohibited unless approved by
ordinance or resolution. No concession or privilege shall be granted unless
approved by ordinance or resolution. The Department shall have no power to
acquire land or property or to accept gifts of real or personal property
without approval of Council, and any property acquired shall be in the name of
the Municipality.
(Ord. 190-1996. Passed 1-28-97.)
   135.03 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Department of Parks and Recreation shall have the power to make rules
and regulations for the government and management thereof, including the power
to fix charges for the use of any Municipally owned and/or controlled park or
recreation facility. All rules, regulations, use charges, amendments and
changes adopted by the Department shall be filed in the office of the Clerk.
All use charges adopted by the Department with respect to the Twinsburg Fitness
Center and Twinsburg Water Park shall be first adopted by Council. This chapter
and rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto shall be enforced by the
Division of Police. Violation of rules and regulations adopted shall be a
violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 23-2023. Passed 3-14-23.)
   135.04 FUNDS.
   The Department of Parks and Recreation shall plan and operate such
recreational facilities and programs with the funds properly appropriated by
Council for such purpose.
(Ord. 33-1965. Passed 4-27-65.)
   135.05 BUDGET.
   The Department of Parks and Recreation shall, before the first day of June
of each year, submit to the Mayor, an estimate of contemplated revenue and
expenditures for the ensuing fiscal year which may be approved in whole or in
part by Council and included in the general municipal budget. The Department
shall operate within the budget so approved and the expenses thereof shall be
payable from the Treasury of the Municipality.
(Ord. 33-1965. Passed 4-27-65.)
   135.06 ANNUAL REPORT.
   The Department of Recreation and Parks shall make an annual report to the
Mayor, showing its operation and expenditures and shall make such other reports
from time to time as may be requested by the Mayor.
(Ord. 33-1965. Passed 4-27-65.)
   135.07 STAFF.
   The Mayor may appoint a Director of Parks and Recreation who shall be the
head of such Department, who shall be responsible directly to the Mayor, and
who shall recommend staff and personnel appointments to the Mayor who then
shall confirm such appointments before the same shall be considered final. The
Director shall have charge of the park, playground and recreation system and of
the recommendation of the appointment and the supervision of qualified
employees of such Department for the effective administration, construction and
development of the system. The Director shall have such other powers and duties
as may from time to time be delegated by the Mayor. The Director shall serve at
the pleasure of the Mayor.
(Ord. 33-1965. Passed 4-27-65.)

   137.01 LAND DEVELOPMENT COMMITTEE.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section

   137.02 ZONING CLASSIFICATION OF PROPERTY WHICH IS ANNEXED.
   (a)   The Zoning use of property in unincorporated territories which shall
become annexed to the City of Twinsburg shall be determined by the use
classification as set forth in the Zoning Ordinance of the unincorporated
territory as of the date of the annexation.
   (b)   Property which is zoned for residential use by the Zoning Ordinance of
the unincorporated territory effective as of the date of annexation shall be
included in that zoning classification of the Zoning Code of the City of
Twinsburg which is closest to the classification in the unincorporated
territory except that, in no event, shall any such territory be included in any
classification which permits less lot frontage or greater density than the
frontage and density permitted by the R-3 classification as set forth at
Section 1143.03 of the Zoning Code.
   (c)   Council may provide for exception to the procedures set forth herein
by resolution and that such resolution shall be referred to the Planning
Commission for consideration and recommendation in accordance with Section
1183.01(a) of the Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 61-1998. Passed 4-28-98.)

CHAPTER 143
Parks and Recreation Commission
143.01   Establishment, term, meetings and duties.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01
      Power to construct recreation centers - see Ohio R.C. 717.01
      Park and Recreation Regulations - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
925
   143.01 ESTABLISHMENT, TERM, MEETINGS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   Established. There is hereby established a Parks and Recreation
Commission. Such Commission shall be comprised of an appointed non-voting
Councilmember and seven inhabitants of the City who are domiciled therein
during their tenure on such Commission, of which number each ward shall be
represented by at least one adult member. One member shall be a senior resident
who is fifty -five (55) years of age or older at the time of the appointment.
One member shall be and remain during his/her term, a resident high school
teenager.
   (b)   Term of Office. All members shall be appointed by Council for terms of
two years except that one teen representative shall be appointed for a one-year
term commencing February 1, 2002.
(Ord. 92-2010. Passed 6-22-10.)
   (c)   Meetings. At its first meeting in each calendar year, the Commission
shall elect from its membership a Chairman, Vice-Chairman, and Secretary. The
appointed Councilmember shall not serve as an officer of the Commission. The
Commission shall meet at the call of the Chairman in order to fulfill the
Commission's duties and responsibilities, but in no event shall it meet more
than six times annually. All meetings shall be announced by public posting, by
newspaper, or at a City Council session, shall be open to the public; and shall
be held upon any public premises designated by the commission. The Commission
may hold study or work sessions as a prelude to any official action. It shall
be bound in procedure by "Robert's Rules of Order Revised", except that the
Commission may depart there from by adopting its own rules, by-laws or
procedures.
(Ord. 18-2017. Passed 3-24-17.)
   (d)   Duties. The Commission shall be an advisory body to the Administration
and to Council, relying upon regular reports from the Department of Parks and
Recreation and its Director through the Mayor. Copies of the Commission's
minutes, reports and recommendations shall regularly be filed with the Clerk of
Council and with the Mayor. The powers and duties of the Commission are to be
general in nature, and shall not be final, determinative or of legislative
effect. The Mayor, and department heads shall furnish advice and assistance to
the Commission upon request to the Mayor. The Commission's duties shall
include, but not be limited to:
      (1)   A review of all City Parks and Recreation facilities and equipment
and the preparation of recommendations concerning such and proposals as to
future facilities and equipment.
      (2)   The development of a survey to be distributed to City residents,
seeking comments about present or proposed Parks and Recreation programs or
events, and the preparation of a summary of the results obtained from such
survey.
      (3)   The preparation of recommendations and/or proposals from programs
or events not presently being offered by the Department of Parks and Recreation
including programs or events for the youth and for the senior citizens of the
City;
      (4)   A review of recommendations or events proposed by the Department of
Parks and Recreation, and the preparation of recommendations as to such
proposals;
      (5)   The coordination of recreational activities with the Twinsburg City
School District in order to avoid unnecessary duplication;
      (6)   The review of all aspects of current programs or events being
offered or sponsored by the Department of Parks and Recreation and the
preparation of an analysis and recommendation report related to such current
programs or events; and
      (7)   Preparation of a report suggesting criteria (for example, minimum
attendance) to be considered in initiating and continuing Parks and Recreation
programs or events, and proposals to assist in making many such programs or
events self-supporting.
         (Ord. 92-2010. Passed 6-22-10.)
CHAPTER 144
Community Relations Board
144.01   Establishment; term; meetings and duties.
   144.01 ESTABLISHMENT; TERM; MEETINGS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   Established. There is hereby established a Community Relations Board.
Such Board shall be comprised of the Mayor, two (2) members of Council, and
three designees of the School Board. It is anticipated that Twinsburg Township,
the Village of Reminderville and any other community seeking representation
will also designate three members of their respective communities to
participate with the Board.
   (b)   Term of Office. All appointed members shall serve for a term of one
year commencing December 1 of the year appointed.
   (c)   Meetings. At its first meeting in each calendar year, the Board shall
elect from its membership a Chairman and Vice-Chairman. The Board shall meet as
needed but at least quarterly at the call of the Chairman in order to fulfill
the Board's duties and responsibilities. Each representative community shall
host at least one meeting of the Board during the course of the year. All
meetings shall be announced by public posting, by newspaper, or at a City
Council session, shall be open to the public; and shall be held upon any public
premises designated by the Board. It shall be bound in procedure by "Robert's
Rules of Order Revised", except that the Board may depart therefrom by adopting
its own rules, by-laws or procedures.
   (d)   Duties. The Board shall be an advisory and recommending body to the
Administration and to Council. Copies of the Board's minutes, reports and
recommendations shall regularly be filed with the Clerk of Council and with the
Mayor. The powers and duties of the Board are to be general in nature, and
shall not be final, determinative or of legislative effect. The Mayor, and
department heads shall furnish advice and assistance to the Board upon request
to the Mayor. The Board's duties shall include, but not be limited to:
      (1)   A review of all contracts, agreements, facilities and services
jointly used between the City of Twinsburg and one or more separate
municipalities and/or public bodies.
      (2)   The development and recommendations for the improvement of
relationships among the City of Twinsburg and other municipal bodies.
      (3)   A review of recommendations or services proposed by City
departments that directly involve or affect other municipal bodies;
      (4)   Any other duties or tasks specifically referred to the Board by
City Council.
         (Ord. 27-2010. Passed 4-13-10.)

CHAPTER 146
Charter Review Oversight Commission
146.01   Establishment; term; meetings and duties.
146.02   Authority.
146.03   Compensation and funding.
   146.01 ESTABLISHMENT; TERM; MEETINGS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   Established. There is hereby established a Charter Review Oversight
Commission. Such Commission shall be comprised of three (3) members of the most
recently seated Charter Review Commission as recommended by the prior Charter
Review Commission and approved by the majority of Council.
   (b)   Term of Office. All appointed members shall serve a term of no more
than five (5) years. The term shall commence with the date of appointment and
terminate on the date of termination of the next Charter Review Commission.
   (c)   Meetings. At its first meeting in each calendar year, the Commission
shall elect a Chairman who shall call the meetings and also be responsible for
maintaining minutes. The Commission shall meet as needed but at least quarterly
at the call of the Chairman in order to fulfill the Commission's duties and
responsibilities. All meetings shall be announced by public posting, by
newspaper, or at a City Council session, shall be open to the public; and shall
be held upon any public premises designated by the Commission. It shall be
bound in procedure by "Robert's Rules of Order Revised" except that the
Commission may depart therefrom by adopting its own rules, by-laws or
procedures.
   (d)   Duties. The Commission shall be an advisory and recommending body to
the Administration, Council and to subsequent Charter Review Commissions.
Copies of the Commission's minutes, reports and recommendations shall regularly
be filed with the Clerk of Council and with the Mayor. The powers and duties of
the Commission are to be general in nature, and shall not be final,
determinative or of legislative effect. The Mayor, Council and department heads
shall furnish advice and assistance to the Commission upon request to the
Mayor. The Board's duties shall include, but not be limited to:
      (1)   Review and monitor Boards, Commissions, Administration and Council
to ensure and maintain compliance with the provisions of the City Charter.
       (2)   Review and monitor pending legislation to ensure and maintain
compliance with the City Charter.
      (3)   Annually the Commission shall prepare and maintain recommendations
for items to be considered by the next Charter Review Commission. At a minimum,
the recommendations shall set forth the specific Charter provision at issue;
the reason for the recommendation; and the proposed remedy.
      (4)   Annually, the Commission shall prepare and maintain an audit
listing all of the legislative actions that are governed by the Charter in
order to assure and maintain compliance with the Charter.
      (5)   Annually, the Commission shall prepare and maintain an audit
listing all of the actions of the Planning Commission that are governed by the
Charter in order to assure and maintain compliance with the Charter.
      (6)   The Commission shall present recommendations and audits to the
Charter Review Commission for consideration at the request of the newly seated
Charter Review Commission.
      (7)   Any other duties or tasks specifically referred to the Commission
by City Council.
         (Ord. 48-2010. Passed 5-11-10.)
   146.02 AUTHORITY.
   The Commission is only a monitoring and recommending body. Members shall
have no voting authority on the Charter Review Commission. No person shall be
permitted to be a member of the Charter Review Oversight Commission and the
Charter Review Commission at the same time. The Oversight Commission shall only
have monitoring and recommending authority over issues directly related to
specific provision of the Charter of the City of Twinsburg.
(Ord. 48-2010. Passed 5-11-10.)
   146.03 COMPENSATION AND FUNDING.
   Members of the Commission shall sit without compensation. The City staff
will provide basic secretarial services for the benefit of the Commission
including copies and publication of agendas and notices.
(Ord. 48-2010. Passed 5-11-10.)
